newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish shares set high, seen losing steam.
newsitem.headline: Polish shares set high, seen losing steam.

text.p: Polish shares rose to a 35-month high and analysts said the bourse, now at 18,339.4 points, might slow its growth or stabilise in the next few sessions as it approaches its all-time March 1994 high of 20,760.3.
The main market's WIG index rose 1.2 percent to 18,339.4 points and turnover fell 9.7 percent to 232.5 million zlotys ($77.5 million) on both markets as 46 issues rose, 22 fell and 20 were flat.

"We are not far from the historic maximum, which is naturally halting growth. It seems to me that the growth will slow and the market will stabilise," said Artur Czerwonski, an analyst at Bank Pekao SA brokerage.
Some analysts said the market, which has risen 38 percent since mid-December, was likely to suffer from significant profit-taking after reaching around 18,500 points.
Some said a correction could pull the WIG index down below 16,000 points.
Analysts said companies' January earnings reports, most of them expected later on Tuesday, were likely to make selected stocks jump or fall on Wednesday.

Analysts said Tuesday's over nine-percent jumps by electromagnetic transmitters maker Relpol, food trader Rolimpex and construction firm Mostostal Krakow were likely caused by speculative play before the release of their earnings reports.

Analysts said the market was unlikely to react to Tuesday's news that Poland's industrial output fell 3.4 percent in January after a 2.1 percent rise in December. Year-on-year industrial output in January was 8.6 percent higher.
Continuous trade amounted to 27.5 million zlotys ($9.2 million) with the WIG 20 index closing at 1,885.7 points, 0.5 percent lower than at the regular session.
